I have a question about non-human carriers.

You know, I really don't know this works for malaria but why could the animals that are around these villages in Sub-Saharan Africa not be vaccinated, you know, cattle and pigs and dogs, and whatever else gets bitten by mosquitoes, and would that not carry the same antibodies?
If you immunize the other animals that might be bitten by the mosquito that's quite true.
You could have other animals serve as a vector for the development of the antibody.
I think, part of the thing is that there's only the major mosquito class that the malaria parasite propagates in is anopheles.
And the anopheles seems to have a preferential taste for humans.
Oh.
Well, would pigs or things that are similar tasting, I guess, to mosquitoes be possible surrogates?
I think, they would be additions but not surrogates.
Thank you very much.
Thanks, Mike.
This sounds a little ghoulish but is it possible to create banks of just human blood that's infected and find some way to have mosquitoes attack it without the people themselves?
Well, that's, in essence, the model system that our investigators use to assess the biological consequences of this antibody.

That is to say what they expose mosquitoes to was a container of blood that contained red blood cells that had the malaria parasite in them, and that had the antibody in it and, basically, put a little membrane between the tube of blood in the mosquito and induce the mosquito to bite and drink of the little tube.
And then they could show that they blocked the maturation of the malaria parasite in the mosquito.
I would think you could but I think you'd have to find good meal substitutes, if you will, that mosquitoes and the right type of mosquito would go after.
I'm talking with Dr. Owen Rennert of the NIH of TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News.
So, we're not substituting human body for mosquitoes.
They are not going for it, at least, in this stage.

I am just calling in to make a comment that it's very interesting to see that after Bill Gates has been putting in the funding and also President Bush provides the initiative - right now, the vaccine for malaria is developing.
But I want to point out a - there is a physician in China who has been doing a great job in this area.
However, he is really lack of funding to push the matters that he developed for.
His name is Gore Chow Lee(ph) and he is well recognized by United Nations.
He has wiped off malaria in China 10 years ago.
And then he went on to help Vietnam to wipe off malaria five years ago.
Right now, he is working in Cambodia and some of the African countries to help to the same thing.
He has a very grand goal of wiping malaria of the earth.
And the method he developed is also very simple and are very inexpensive.
However, he is really lack of funding push that in mass to help with this - wipe off the world.
And that's his goal.
I just want to make that comment.
I tried helping by just don't know the right channel to get through and to make it happen.
And to go through the FDA channel, takes too long and too much resource that he does not have.
But, currently, the proven record is malaria is extinct in China 10 years ago, in Vietnam five years ago.
All right.
Dr. Rennert, you heard anything about this?
No.
I am afraid I don't know it but that doesn't mean anything.
What I simply would encourage in response to the comments, I think, there are multiple approaches that are being explored throughout the world to eradicate malaria.

And, I think, clearly, independent of the present push and recognition of that, it is an old problem and a problem that has merited approaches over time and it's unfortunate that we haven't made more progress.

The other part I'd, sort of, stress is, you know, that relates a little bit even to the return of certain insecticides and the fact is that developing a blocking antibody or another approach is, in essence, an extension of the notion of eradicating the vector, the host, for the mosquito and its cycle outside of the human.
And one cheap way that people have suggested to reduce the incidents of malaria is to reintroduce things like DDT and spray and kill the mosquitoes.
So there are multiple approaches, and, I think, all of them need to be explored, tested and then put into action.
All right.
Dr. Rennert.

It sounds like if something may happen soon, at least, in human wise.

We're going to meet a coach now not for athletes but for people trying to stop using drugs.
Charlie Oen is a peer-recovery coach in Lima, Ohio.

If you were writing Charlie Oen's life story, you might say it's been grim.

They're like, dude, do you want these morphines?

I do, you know?

I'm here for doing this.

And I didn't want to let anybody else down, including, like, myself.
